author: sergio carmona
title: Protegen miles huevos de tortuga en Quintana Roo, ante amenaza del huracán ‘Beryl’
text: Protegen miles huevos de tortuga en Quintana Roo, ante amenaza del huracán ‘Beryl’ [Sergio Carmona](/autor/-/meta/sergio-carmona) Rescataron huevos de tortuga para evitar que las fuertes rachas de viento y la lluvia causen estragos negativos En Quintana Roo, las autoridades y la ciudadanía ya se preparan para el momento en que el huracán “Beryl” toque tierra en la madrugada del viernes, por esto el Programa de Protección de la [Tortuga Marina](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chelonioidea) de Cancún convocó a voluntarios para salvaguardar más de 100 mil huevos de quelonio distribuidos en las costas de Cancún. Fue durante las primeras horas del día cuando los integrantes del programa se situaron en playa Delfines, una de las más concurridas por los turistas, ahí rescataron huevos de tortuga para evitar que las fuertes rachas de viento y la lluvia causen estragos negativos. TE PUEDE INTERESAR: [Ante la amenaza del huracán “Beryl” 33.7 mil turistas abandonan el Caribe mexicano](https://vanguardia.com.mx/noticias/nacional/ante-la-amenaza-del-huracan-beryl-337-mil-turistas-abandonan-el-caribe-mexicano-KH12513494) “En caso de recibir algún tipo de fenómeno meteorológico podemos tener algún tipo de deslave en la arena, nos alcanza la marea, se nos puede dañar el corral tortuguero y obviamente esto dañaría significantemente los corrales de tortugas y, por tanto, los niños”, así lo explicó la directora de Ecología, Tania Fernández. Existen playas ubicadas en Puerto Escondido, en Oaxaca, o Playa Delfines, en Cancún, que año tras año realizan la liberación de tortugas, por esto es muy importante tener un programa que salvaguarde su salud, en 1994 nació el Programa de Protección a la Tortuga Marina. Actualmente, se ubican en Isla Mujeres, Contoy, Cozumel, Playa del Carmen y Holbox y tienen el objetivo de crear conciencia en el sector hotelero sobre la importancia de esta especie, informar que la tortuga corre el peligro de extinguirse y está protegida por el nivel federal. Como parte del programa y su forma de trabajar, revelaron que no darán a conocer la ubicación a la que serán trasladadas, esto por el peligro que corren diariamente. QUINTANA ROO ANUNCIA REFUGIOS TEMPORALES El gobierno de Cancún anunció en los recientes días que se instalarán distintos refugios temporales para todas las personas que se encuentren en la zona, algo que le alegró el corazón a los ciudadanos es que también habrá refugio para mascotas. De momento cuentan con 87 refugios temporales para recibir a 23 mil personas y también uno que es totalmente pet friendly, es decir, amigable con los animales, este se ubica en la primera Ek Balam y desde el 2019 lo instalaron. TE PUEDE INTERESAR: [Huracán Beryl impactará Quintana Roo como categoría 1 en la madrugada del viernes, advierte Protección Civil](https://vanguardia.com.mx/noticias/huracan-beryl-impactara-quintana-roo-como-categoria-1-en-la-madrugada-del-viernes-advierte-proteccion-civil-FH12511884) Durante la conferencia de prensa de la Sesión Permanente del Comité Operativo Especializado en Fenómenos Hidrometeorológicos de la Temporada 2024, se informó que Pablo Gutiérrez Fernández, Primer Regidor y responsable de la Presidencia Municipal del Ayuntamiento de Benito Juárez, estuvo a cargo de la presidencia. Con información de medios

author: Admin
title: New computer vision tool wins prize for social impact
text:
AMHERST, Mass. – A team of computer scientists at the University of Massachusetts Amherst working on two different problems—how to quickly detect damaged buildings in crisis zones and how to accurately estimate the size of bird flocks—recently announced an AI framework that can do both. The framework, called DISCount, blends the speed and massive data-crunching power of artificial intelligence with the reliability of human analysis to quickly deliver reliable estimates that can quickly pinpoint and count specific features from very large collections of images. The research, published by the Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence , has been recognized by that association with an award for the best paper on AI for social impact .
Credit: Pérez et al., 10.1609/aaai.v38i20.30235
AMHERST, Mass. – A team of computer scientists at the University of Massachusetts Amherst working on two different problems—how to quickly detect damaged buildings in crisis zones and how to accurately estimate the size of bird flocks—recently announced an AI framework that can do both. The framework, called DISCount, blends the speed and massive data-crunching power of artificial intelligence with the reliability of human analysis to quickly deliver reliable estimates that can quickly pinpoint and count specific features from very large collections of images. The research, published by the Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence , has been recognized by that association with an award for the best paper on AI for social impact .
“DISCount came together as two very different applications,” says Subhransu Maji , associate professor of information and computer sciences at UMass Amherst and one of the paper’s authors. “ Through UMass Amherst’s Center for Data Science , we have been working with the Red Cross for years in helping them to build a computer vision tool that could accurately count buildings damaged during events like earthquakes or wars. At the same time, we were helping ornithologists at Colorado State University and the University of Oklahoma interested in using weather radar data to get accurate estimates of the size of bird flocks.”
Maji and his co-authors, lead author Gustavo Pérez , who completed this research as part of his doctoral training at UMass Amherst, and Dan Sheldon , associate professor of information and computer sciences at UMass Amherst, thought they could solve the damaged-buildings-and-bird-flock problems with computer vision, a type of AI that can scan enormous archives of images in search of something particular—a bird, a rubble pile—and count it.
But the team was running into the same roadblocks on each project: “the standard computer visions models were not accurate enough,” says Pérez. “We wanted to build automated tools that could be used by non-AI experts, but which could provide a higher degree of reliability.”
The answer, says Sheldon, was to fundamentally rethink the typical approaches to solving counting problems.
“Typically, you either have humans do time-intensive and accurate hand-counts of a very small data set, or you have computer vision run less-accurate automated counts of enormous data sets,” Sheldon says. “We thought: why not do both?”
DISCount is a framework that can work with any already existing AI computer vision model. It works by using the AI to analyze the very large data sets—say, all the images taken of a particular region in a decade—to determine which particular smaller set of data a human researcher should look at. This smaller set could, for example, be all the images from a few critical days that the computer vision model has determined best show the extent of building damage in that region. The human researcher could then hand-count the damaged buildings from the much smaller set of images and the algorithm will use them to extrapolate the number of buildings affected across the entire region. Finally, DISCount will estimate how accurate the human-derived estimate is.
“DISCount works significantly better than random sampling for the tasks we considered,” says Pérez. “And part of the beauty of our framework is that it is compatible with any computer-vision model, which lets the researcher select the best AI approach for their needs. Because it also gives a confidence interval, it gives researchers the ability to make informed judgments about how good their estimates are.”
“In retrospect, we had a relatively simple idea,” says Sheldon. “But that small mental shift—that we didn’t have to choose between human and artificial intelligence, has let us build a tool that is faster, more comprehensive, and more reliable than either approach alone.”
Contacts: Subhransu Maji, smaji@cs.umass.edu
Daegan Miller, drmiller@umass.edu

organizations.name: association for the advancement of artificial intelligence

author: 李響
title: 【新思想引領新征程】植樹增綠共建美麗中國_時政要聞_台灣網
text:
央視網消息 （新聞聯播）：3月12日是植樹節，各地認真踐行習近平生態文明思想，為建設美麗中國增綠添彩，共同譜寫人與自然和諧共生的中國式現代化新篇章。
　　草木蔓發，春山可望，廣袤中華大地迎來植樹造林好時節。
　　位於塔克拉瑪幹沙漠南緣的新疆策勒，當地群眾正在種植紅棗、梭梭等喬木灌木，今年將完成防沙治沙52.78萬畝，築牢沙漠邊緣的綠色屏障。
　　地處長江中下游的湖南臨武西山國有林場，工作人員正在補植楠木、紅豆杉，今年將科學培育58萬株珍貴苗木，精準提升森林品質，提高涵養水源和固碳增匯能力。
　　從南到北，一片片新綠初綻，“北方擴綠、南方提質”的科學綠化新格局正加快構建。
　　森林是陸地生態的主體，是國家、民族最大的生存資本。習近平總書記強調，必須從中華民族歷史發展的高度來看待這個問題，為子孫後代留下美麗家園，讓歷史的春秋之筆為當代中國人留下正能量的記錄。
　　總書記率先垂范，連續12年參加首都義務植樹活動，強調綠化祖國要擴綠、興綠、護綠並舉。從全面推行林長制，到深化集體林權制度改革，從創建設立國家公園、國家植物園，到統籌山水林田湖草沙系統治理，總書記引領推動國土綠化不斷深化。
　　擴綠、興綠、護綠並舉，如今，我國國土綠化高品質發展邁上新臺階。
　　全國綠化委員會辦公室今天公佈的中國國土綠化狀況公報顯示，2024年，我國完成造林6669萬畝，種草改良4836萬畝，治理沙化石漠化土地3683萬畝，美麗中國綠色成色更足。
　　如今，我國已建成國家森林城市212個，城市每人平均公園綠地面積達到15.65平方米，村莊綠化覆蓋率超過32%。林業産業總産值突破10萬億元。
　　如今，我國森林覆蓋率超過25%，森林蓄積量達200多億立方米，草原綜合植被蓋度穩定在50%以上，成為全球增綠最快最多的國家，人工林面積居世界第一。
　　黨的二十屆三中全會對建設美麗中國作出一系列部署，一項項舉措加快落地。
　　今年，“三北”工程攻堅戰已安排240多個項目，下達中央資金209億元，確保及時開工，築牢北疆綠色長城。
　　內蒙古“三北”攻堅戰任務量佔全國近一半，今年將完成防沙治沙2000萬畝以上。眼下，庫布其沙漠北緣，長達420公里的沿黃鎖邊林草帶進入決戰期。當地示範應用無人機、沙障鋪設機等50多種新裝備，治沙質效大大提升。
　　今年，我國持續組織實施一批重要生態系統保護和修復重大工程及國土綠化示範項目，以流域、山系為基本單位，聚焦突出生態問題，統籌推進山水林田湖草沙一體化保護和系統治理，提升重點區域治理成效。
　　今年，我國將全面加強國土綠化項目科學化、精細化管理，實行用地、用水、用苗、技術措施合理性評價和國土綠化任務落地上圖，因地制宜提升林草生態系統多種功能，提高國土綠化品質效益。
　　荒山披錦繡，沙漠變綠洲。今年，我國計劃完成國土綠化任務1億畝以上，深入推進國土綠化高品質發展，讓錦繡河山造福人民，繪出美麗中國的更新畫卷。
[責任編輯：李響]

author: , Salinas Californian
title: Dreamers eligible for health insurance through Covered California for first time this year
text: Dreamers eligible for health insurance through Covered California for first time this year Dreamers in the Golden State are able to sign up for a health plan through the [Covered California](https://www.coveredca.com/) healthcare exchange for the first time this year. Due to a [federal rule change](https://www.federalregister.gov/public-inspection/current) earlier this year at the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, eligible recipients of DACA (Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals) can sign up for a health plan and receive financial help if they qualify. “HHS is committed to making health coverage accessible for people DACA recipients – Dreamers – who have worked hard to live the American dream. Dreamers are our neighbors and friends; they are students, teachers, social workers, doctors, and nurses. More importantly, they are fellow Americans,” [said HHS Secretary Xavier Becerra, in a statement announcing the rule change earlier this year](https://www.hhs.gov/about/news/2024/05/03/hhs-finalizes-policies-increase-access-health-coverage-daca-recipients.html). “More than one-third of DACA recipients currently do not have health insurance, so making them eligible to enroll in coverage will improve their health and wellbeing and help the overall economy.” As a result of this rule, DACA recipients and other newly eligible individuals will qualify for a special enrollment period to select a health plan through the Marketplace during the 60 days following the rule’s Nov. 1 effective date. The timing also corresponds with the 2025 Open Enrollment Period, which will help ensure that newly eligible individuals are able to enroll in coverage. Eligible DACA applicants can get coverage as soon as Dec. 1, if they apply in November To facilitate the process, Covered California set up a special enrollment period from Nov. 1 to Dec. 31, to help DACA recipients get health and dental insurance for the rest of 2024 year if they sign up in November. Coverage could start as soon as Dec. 1. To sign up, applicants select the “gained lawful presence” option from the list in the special enrollment period section when applying. The special enrollment period overlaps with Covered California’s regular open-enrollment period, which means DACA recipients can also sign up for health and dental insurance for 2025 during this time. What is DACA? DACA (Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals) is a policy established in 2012 that enables eligible undocumented immigrants who were brought to the United States as children to avoid deportation and receive a Social Security number, work permit and driver’s license to live and work legally in the States. DACA approvals are valid for two years at a time. To be eligible for DACA, an applicant must have been younger than 31 years old on June 15, 2012, or born on or later than June 16, 1981, and have adhered to other residency, education, and security requirements. How many DACA recipients are there in California? California has the most active DACA recipients of any state in the United States, with 164,320 as of 2023, [according to US Citizen and Immigration Services](https://www.uscis.gov/sites/default/files/document/data/Active_DACA_Recipients_March_FY23_qtr2.pdf). Texas has the second most DACA recipients at 95,430. There are 578,680 total DACA recipients across the United States.
